newsitem.title: USA: CBOT corn and soybeans fall further on forecast.
newsitem.headline: CBOT corn and soybeans fall further on forecast.

text.p: CBOT corn and soybean futures fell further on Monday, led by new-crop months on long-range forecasts which suggested a wetter pattern next week for the U.S. Midwest, traders said.
"Jon Davis is talking a lot of rain next week across the belt," said Vic Lespinasse of Dean Witter.
Smith Barney meteorologist Jon Davis said in his daily update that long-range forecasts suggest a shift to a wetter pattern next week for the U.S. Midwest.

"This morning's (Monday) computer guidance indicates that by this weekend and next week (the week of August 11) there will be some changes in the pattern," Davis wrote. "Plain and simply, this pattern is much more favorable for widespread rains in the central U.S."
Corn and soybeans had rallied in opening trade amid forecasts for another dry week in the U.S. Midwest but pit sources said the long-range outlook eased concerns of moisture stress.
At 1053 CDT, soybeans were down 11-3/4 to two cents per bushel with November down 10 at $6.45-1/2.
Corn was off 5-3/4 to 2-3/4 cents per bushel with December down 4-1/2 at $2.64-1/2.
